feed.title: 最近的问题 - Chemistry Stack Exchange; ; ; ;最近 30 个来自chemistry.stackexchange.com; ;2023-09-29T17:35 ：54Z ; ;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/feeds; ;https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/rdf; <条目>; ;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/q/176568; ;0; ;有效核心潜力及其“相应的Pople”基础集</stitle>; <category schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="quantum-chemistry">;</类别>; <类别方案=“https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags”术语=“计算化学”>;</类别>; <类别方案=“https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags”术语= “密度功能理论”>;</类别>; <类别方案=“https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags”术语=“基础设置”>;</类别>;<作者>;<名称>;MrAmateurChem</名称>; <uri>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/138007</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/176568/ effective-core-pottials -and-their-corresponding-pople-basis-set" rel="alternate"/>; <发布>;2023-09-29T15:57:12Z</发布>; <更新>;2023-09-29T15:57:12Z</更新>; <summary type="html">; <p>;阅读<a href="http://ursula.chem.yale.edu/%7Ebatista/classes/tutorials/gaussian/ECP_bases.pdf" rel="nofollow noreferrer">;耶鲁大学的讲义</a>;显示作者将 ECP 与 Pople 基组关联起来。作者说SDD的相应基础集是6-31G，Def2TZV是6-311G，LANL2MB是STO-3G，等等......我对两者之间的相关性感到困惑，因为我认为它们完全不同不能直接相关的 LCAO 集。这些 ECP 之一的一部分是用 Pople 基组构建的吗？还是我误解了？</p>; <p>;方向（出版物、文章等的链接）将不胜感激，以便我可以澄清我的误解并了解这一点，并消除知识上的任何差距。谢谢。</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/q/176565</id>; <re:rank schema="https://chemistry .stackexchange.com">;1</re:rank>; <title type="text">;高锰酸钾在哪种介质中是更好的氧化剂？</stitle>; <category schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com /标签”术语=“无机化学”>;</类别>; <类别方案=“https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags”术语=“电化学”>;</类别>; <类别方案=“https：/ /chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="redox">;</category>; <作者>; <name>;thundercrypt</name>; <uri>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/133245</uri>; </作者>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/176565/in-which-medium-is-potassium-permanganate-a-better-oxys-agent" rel="alternate"/>; <published>;2023-09-29T11:47:26Z</published>; <updated>;2023-09-29T12:38:39Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;我刚才在上化学课，我的化学老师给了我们三个反应：</p>; <p>;反应 1: <span class="math-container">;$\ce{MnO4^- + e- ->;; + MnO4^2-（基础介质）}$</span>;</p>; <p>;反应2：<span class="math-container">;$\ce{MnO4^- + 4H+ + 3e- ->; + MnO2 + 2H2O（中性或近中性介质）}$</span>;</p>; <p>;反应 3：<span class="math-container">;$\ce{MnO4^- + 8H+ + 5e- - >; + Mn^2+ + 4H2O（酸性介质）}$</span>;</p>; <p>;n 因子为 <span class="math-container">;$n_1=1$</span>;，<分别是span class="math-container">;$n_2=3$</span>;和<span class="math-container">;$n_3=5$</span>;。</p>; <p>;现在，当我的老师说 <span class="math-container">;$\ce{KMnO4}$</span>; 是酸性介质中最好的氧化剂时，问题就出现了。他说这是因为 <span class="math-container">;$\ce{KMnO4}$</span>; 在酸性介质中具有最大的 n 因子。我决定在我的书（NCERT，这是我们在印度使用的标准书）中进行一些事实核查，我发现这些反应中的每一个都具有 <span class="math-container" 的还原潜力>;$E^⦵_1 = +0.56 \mathrm{V}$</span>;、<span class="math-container">;$E^⦵_2 = +1.69 \mathrm{V}$</span>;，以及<span class="math-container">;$E^⦵_3 = +1.52 \mathrm{V}$</span>; 分别，这使我得出结论， <span class="math-container">;$\如果我们根据还原电位的实验数据来看，ce{KMnO4}$</span>;是中性介质中较好的氧化剂。</p>; <p>;除此之外，我的书中还提到：“虽然很多反应可以通过考虑氧化还原电位来理解，反应动力学也是一个重要因素。高锰酸盐位于 <span class="math-container">;$\ce{[H+]}$</span>; <span class="math-container">;$=$</span>; <span class="math-container “$1$</span>; 应该会氧化水，但实际上反应非常缓慢，除非存在锰 (II) 离子或温度升高。”它没有进一步详细说明，但这给了我一个暗示，不知何故，该反应的动力学也很重要。</p>; <p>;我这边的补充：如果我们要计算标准吉布斯自由能根据给定的氧化还原电位，我们会发现第三个反应的吉布斯自由能最负。这无论如何都会产生影响吗？既然它“更自发”，那么在这种情况下我们是否可以认为它是一种更好的氧化剂？</p>; <p>;所以我的最后一个问题是，这本书是正确的还是我的老师是正确的？如果我的老师是正确的，那么我应该如何知道通过还原电位或通过 n 因子来判断氧化性质？看来我的老师更重视化学计量学，而这本书更重视动力学和热力学。</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/ q/176564</id>; <re:rank schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com">;-2</re:rank>; <title type="text">;混合不同比例的 NaOH 和 NaOH 时的温度变化H2SO4 溶液</stitle>; <category schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="acid-base">;</category>; <发布>;2023- 09-29T11:15:22Z</published>; <updated>;2023-09-29T12:54:09Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;相同条件下，混合多少ml 1M < span class="math-container">;$\ce{KOH}$</span>; 溶液和 0​​.5M <span class="math-container">;$\ce{H2SO4}$</span>; 溶液组成总计100ml 的体积会导致温度升高？</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/q/176562</id>; <re:rank schema= "https://chemistry.stackexchange.com">;0</re:rank>; <title type="text">;了解锌和氢氧化钠反应形成的锌酸钠 (Na2ZnO2) 的成分</stitle>; <类别方案="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="acid-base">;</category>; <category schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="reaction-mechanism" >;</类别>; <作者>; <名称>;uggupuggu </名称>; <uri>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/137781</uri>; </作者>; <link href="https://chemistry .stackexchange.com/questions/176562/understanding-the-composition-of-sodium-zincate-na2zno2-formed-from-zinc-and-s" rel="alternate"/>; <已发布>;2023-09-29T06:43 :00Z</published>; <updated>;2023-09-29T12:48:38Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;我最近进行了一项实验，将锌与氢氧化钠反应形成钠锌酸盐（Na<sub>;2</sub>;ZnO<sub>;2</sub>;）。但是，我无法理解为什么锌酸钠的成分为 Na<sub>;2</sub>;ZnO<sub>;2</sub>;。有人可以解释导致这种特定成分的化学反应和原理吗？此外，哪些因素影响该反应的化学计量，以及它与锌酸钠的性质有何关系？</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com /q/176554</id>; <re:rank schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com">;1</re:rank>; <title type="text">;为什么离子化合物的样品会碎成碎片，但这些片段不会再次组合成更大的样本？</stitle>; <category schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="ions">;</category>; <category schema="https: //chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="ionic-compounds">;</category>; <作者>; <名称>;鲍勃</名称>; <uri>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/137186​​< /uri>; </author>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/176554/why-do-samples-of-ionic-compounds-break-into-pieces-but-the-pieces- do-not-combi" rel="alternate"/>; <发布>;2023-09-29T01:18:16Z</发布>; <更新>;2023-09-29T16:29:05Z</更新>; <summary type=" html">; <p>;离子化合物的一个独特特性是它们很脆。我们得知这是因为当对晶格施加力时，离子会移动，导致正离子排斥正离子，负离子排斥负离子。结果，晶格破碎。因此离子化合物是脆性的。对我来说这是合乎逻辑的。</p>; <p>;但是，使用类似的直觉，我们是否也可以将破碎的碎片重新组合在一起。在某些时候，我们应该让带相反电荷的离子对齐，从而使破碎的碎片再次聚集在一起。显然，当我们把食盐放在一起时，它们不会再聚在一起。那么我的直觉从根本上来说有什么问题吗？</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/q/176552</id>; <re:rank schema ="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com">;0</re:rank>; <title type="text">;测量原子内电子、质子和中子的数量</stitle>; <category schema=" https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="电子">;</category>; <category schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="atoms">;</category>; <类别方案=“https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags”术语=“质子”>;</类别>;<类别方案=“https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags”术语=“中子”>;< /category>; <作者>; <名称>;doca</名称>; <uri>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/137982</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange .com/questions/176552/measurement-of-the-number-of-electrons-protons-and-neutrons-inside-an-atom" rel="alternate"/>; <已发布>;2023-09-28T22:32:15Z </published>; <updated>;2023-09-29T04:49:16Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;我们如何测量原子内质子、电子和中子的数量？例如，可以进行哪些实验来确定铁原子包含 26 个质子？</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/q/176550 </id>; <re:rank schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com">;-2</re:rank>; <title type="text">;变性和天然蛋白质的迁移率</stitle>; <category方案=“https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags”术语=“生物化学”>;</类别>;<作者>;<名称>;Jaehyun Ahn</名称>;<uri>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/用户/72807</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/176550/denatured-and-native- Proteins-migration-rate" rel="alternate"/>; < Publication>;2023-09-28T21:08:56Z</published>; <updated>;2023-09-28T21:08:56Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;变性蛋白质的迁移速度总是比原生蛋白质慢吗蛋白质？</p>; <p>;我想知道如果蛋白质没有变性，折叠会如何影响凝胶过滤过程中的迁移速率。</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https: //chemistry.stackexchange.com/q/176549</id>; <re:rank schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com">;-5</re:rank>; <title type="text">;什么是我用 KNO3 在水中制作的东西吗？</stitle>; <category schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="electrochemistry">;</category>; <category schema="https: //chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="电解">;</category>; <作者>; <名称>;布鲁诺·里埃拉</名称>; <uri>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/137957</ uri>; </author>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/176549/what-is-the-thing-i-made-in-water-with-kno3-i-made" rel ="alternate"/>; <发布>;2023-09-28T21:05:00Z</发布>; <更新>;2023-09-29T10:53:44Z</更新>; <summary type="html">; <p>;所以我尝试用<strong>;水和硝酸钾</strong>;电解（用于园艺，所以不是最纯净的东西）我在谷歌中看到的反应说它会分解成氧气和氢气，但这可能是用石墨电极，但是我用了<strong>;铁钉</strong>;，电解后有<strong>;白色微固体，不溶于水</strong>;沉在烧瓶底部，任何人都知道它是什么？ </p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/q/176548</id>; <re:rank schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange .com">;2</re:rank>; <title type="text">;解释以下反应的机理，该反应涉及双构型反转的 1,2-烷基迁移</stitle>; <category schema=" https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="organic-chemistry">;</category>; <category schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="reaction-mechanism">;< /类别>; <类别方案=“https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags”术语=“立体化学”>;</类别>; <类别方案=“https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags”术语=“水解">;</类别>; <类别方案="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="rearrangements">;</类别>; <作者>; <名称>;环丙醇</名称>; <uri>;https： //chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/113430</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/176548/explain-the-mechanism-of-the-following-反应-其中-涉及-a-1-2-烷基-migr" rel="alternate"/>; <发布>;2023-09-28T19:22:48Z</发布>; <更新>;2023-09-29T06:35： 38Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;我遇到了以下反应，据说其机制涉及构型双反转的 1,2-烷基迁移。使用的试剂是亚硝酸（原位生成），然后进行酸性水解。</p>; <p>;<a href="https://i.stack.imgur.com/AzRtg.png" rel="nofollow noreferrer" >;<img src="https://i.stack.imgur.com/AzRtg.png" alt="在此处输入图像描述" />;</a>;</p>; <p>;我得到一个提示，第一个步骤涉及亚硝酸与NH基团的反应。但是，我无法理解反应是如何进行的。谁能解释一下这个机制吗？</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/q/176542</id>; <re:rank schema="https: //chemistry.stackexchange.com">;2</re:rank>; <title type="text">;对于酸度来说，大小和电负性哪个更重要？</stitle>; <category schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange. com/tags" term="organic-chemistry">;</category>; <category schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="acid-base">;</category>; <category schema=" https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="resonance">;</category>; <category schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="Hydrogen">;</category>; <作者>; <名称>;Max0815 </名称>; <uri>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/74326</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions /176542/is-size-or-electricnegativity-more-important-in-acidity" rel="alternate"/>; <发布>;2023-09-28T17:12:12Z</发布>; <更新>;2023-09-29T03 :13:36Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;对于下面的分子，是含氧的氢的酸性更强还是含硫的分子更酸性？</p>; <p>;<a href ="https://i.stack.imgur.com/wYckq.png" rel="nofollow noreferrer">;<img src="https://i.stack.imgur.com/wYckq.png" alt="Enter图像描述在这里” />;</a>;</p>; <p>;由于两个部分具有相同数量的共振结构，我猜这只是归结为原子的电负性或大小是否优先决定是否质子的酸性更强。</p>; <p>;那么，在酸性中，大小和电负性哪个更重要？</p>; <p>;提前致谢！</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/q/176536</id>; <re:rank schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com">;5</re:rank>; <title type=" text">;如果两种化合物（一种酸性和一种碱性）在熔融态/纯态下相互添加，会发生酸碱反应吗？</stitle>; <category schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange .com/tags" term="acid-base">;</category>; <作者>; <名称>;Ridam Sharma</名称>; <uri>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/136796</uri>; < /author>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/176536/can-acid-base-reaction-occur-if-two-compounds-one-acidic-and-one-basic-are-添加“ rel =“alternate”/>; <发布>; 2023-09-28T08：59：06Z </发布>; <更新>; 2023-09-28T18：06：54Z </更新>; <summary type =“html”>; < p>;我是一名 14 岁的学生，有人告诉我，酸碱反应<strong>;仅</strong>;发生在水溶液中，因为它们只在水溶液中产生离子，我不禁想知道它们是否可以如果这两种化合物以纯态或熔融态相互添加，就会发生这种情况。</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/q /176534</id>; <re:rank schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com">;1</re:rank>; <title type="text">;为什么环己烷比苯更易极化？</stitle >; <类别方案=“https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags”术语=“物理化学”>;</类别>; <类别方案=“https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags”术语=“量子化学">;</类别>; <类别方案=“https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags”术语=“分子轨道理论”>;</类别>; <类别方案=“https://chemistry” .stackexchange.com/tags" term="electronegativity">;</category>; <category schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="physical-organic-chemistry">;</category>; <作者>; <名称>;麦金利</名称>; <uri>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/109188</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/ 176534/为什么-is-环己烷-比苯更易极化" rel="alternate"/>; <发布>;2023-09-28T05:43:56Z</发布>; <更新>;2023-09-28T05:43： 56Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;查看<a href="https://www.semanticscholar.org/paper/Efficient-modelling-of-线性-电子-in-using-Gobre /4ac6258cca56f59950617707283408a7a0695e6c/figure/3" rel="nofollow noreferrer">;图4.2</a>;，我们可以通过实验看到环己烷比苯更容易极化。</p>; <p>;为什么会这样？</p >; <p>;直观上，我认为由于苯中的轨道更加离域，苯中的电子可以在施加电场的反应中移动更远，从而产生更大的偶极子并且比局域中可能的极化程度更高。环己烷的轨道。</p>; <p>;我能想到的唯一反驳是，苯中的碳是 SP2，因此比环己烷中的 SP3 碳更具电负性，因此即使电子有更多的空间进行反应在苯中施加电场时，它们与原子核的结合更紧密，因此形成的偶极子较少。然而，这个论点对我来说似乎没有说服力。</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/q/176533</id>; < re:rank schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com">;0</re:rank>; <title type="text">;为什么威廉姆森的乙醚合成只遵循 Sn2 机制</stitle>; <category schema=" https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="organic-chemistry">;</category>; <category schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="reaction-mechanism">;< /category>; <作者>; <名称>;Anirudh Panguluri</名称>; <uri>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/137692</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://chemistry. stackexchange.com/questions/176533/why-does-williamsons-ether-synthesis-only-follow-sn2-mechanism" rel="alternate"/>; <已发布>;2023-09-28T04:41:38Z</已发布>; < Updated>;2023-09-28T17:27:56Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;我是一名学习化学的高中生，我对有机化学的了解非常有限，所以请原谅我问一个无意义的问题。</p>; <p>;在练习有机时，我遇到了以下问题：<a href="https://i.stack.imgur.com/gCW93.jpg" rel="nofollow noreferrer" >;<img src="https://i.stack.imgur.com/gCW93.jpg" alt="在此处输入图像描述" />;</a>;</p>; <p>;现在我的思考过程是，选项A 通过 Sn2 机制发生，如果选项 B 必须发生，则将通过 Sn1 机制发生。我的化学老师告诉我，如果反应的卤化物是三级卤化物，它会更喜欢 Sn1 途径，而初级卤化物更喜欢 Sn2 途径。答案表明选项 A 是正确的，因为 Williamson 醚合成始终遵循 Sn2 途径。为什么它不能遵循 Sn1 途径，在适当的情况下（极性质子溶剂），这将使两个反应都可行。有朋友说这里发生了消除反应，Sn1不可能，因为存在消除反应。但为什么 Sn1 不可能呢？</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/q/176531</id>; <re:rank schema="https ://chemistry.stackexchange.com">;1</re:rank>; <title type="text">;是什么使苯环上的质子转变为更低的 ppm？</stitle>; <category schema="https://chemistry .stackexchange.com/tags" term="organic-chemistry">;</category>; <category schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="spectroscopy">;</category>; <category schema= “https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags” term="nmr-spectroscopy">;</category>; <作者>; <name>;ilovecats</name>; <uri>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/users /137959</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/176531/what-shifts-protons-on-a-苯环-to-lower-ppm" rel ="alternate"/>; <发布>;2023-09-28T02:15:54Z</发布>; <更新>;2023-09-28T20:13:35Z</更新>; <summary type="html">; <p>;为什么这些质子出现在 6.9 和 6.93 ppm 处，<strong>;ppm 值</strong>;较低吗？我认为这是由于各向异性效应，特别是我认为循环的 (pi) 电子感应了一个磁场，导致它们经历更强的净磁场，而那些较低的净磁场则不受感应磁场的影响。这显然是由于共振造成的。怎么会是共振呢？电子循环（环电流）是否不会影响所有质子，或者共振是某些质子比其他质子低的主要原因？</p>; <p>;<a href="https://i.stack.imgur. com/xSfio.png" rel="nofollow noreferrer">;<img src="https://i.stack.imgur.com/xSfio.png" alt="Anisole" />;</a>;</p>; < /summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/q/176529</id>; <re:rank schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com">;2< /re:rank>; <title type="text">;定向金属化中锂化位点的问题</stitle>; <category schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="organic-chemistry">;< /category>; <作者>; <名称>;wayrese </名称>; <uri>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/137130</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange .com/questions/176529/question-on-lithiation-site-in-directed-metalation" rel="alternate"/>; <发布>;2023-09-27T21:45:08Z</发布>; <更新>;2023-09 -27T21:45:08Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;我从<a href="https://www.scripps.edu/baran/images/grpmtgpdf/Krawczuk_March_08. pdf" rel="nofollow noreferrer">;Baran小组会议材料</a>; 这里，为什么C2位置没有发生锂化？为什么 tBuLi 仅专门针对 C4 职位提起诉讼？</p>; <p>;<a href="https://i.stack.imgur.com/JTWjO.png" rel="nofollow noreferrer">;<img src=" https://i.stack.imgur.com/JTWjO.png" alt="在此处输入图像描述" />;</a>;</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https: //chemistry.stackexchange.com/q/176528</id>; <re:rank schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com">;-4</re:rank>; <title type="text">;混合两种解决方案：如何解决此类问题，有什么窍门吗？</stitle>; <category schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="solutions">;</category>; <author>; <name >;亚历山大</名称>; <uri>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/137956</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/176528/mixing -两个解决方案-如何解决此类问题-is-there-a-trick" rel="alternate"/>; <发布>;2023-09-27T21:12:04Z</发布>; <更新>;2023 -09-28T13:36:59Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;两个容器装有盐溶液，第一个容器所含溶液比第二个容器少 1 升。第一个容器中溶液中盐的质量浓度为 10%，第二个容器中的盐质量浓度为 20%。将两种溶液倒入第三个容器后，得到新溶液，其浓度为16%。每个容器最初有多少溶液（体积）？</p>; <p>;我只是想知道这样的问题是如何解决的。如果您能帮助我理解，我将非常感激。来自七年级。</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/q/176527</id>; <re:rank schema="https:/ /chemistry.stackexchange.com">;-2</re:rank>; <title type="text">;烯丙水解中2度>;1度>;3度碳的反应顺序的原因[关闭]</stitle>; <category schema= “https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags” term =“organic-chemistry”>; </类别>; <类别方案=“https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags”term =“reaction-mechanism”>; </类别>; <类别方案="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="alcohols">;</类别>; <作者>; <名称>;sussy baka</名称>; <uri>;https:// Chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/137954</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/176527/reason-for-reactivity-order-of-2 Degree1 Degree3- Degree- Carbon-in-allylic-Hydrol" rel="alternate"/>; <发布>;2023-09-27T18:33:56Z</发布>; <更新>;2023-09-27T18:33:56Z</更新>; <摘要类型="html">; <p>;我们的老师告诉我们，在烯丙基羟基化反应中，2<em>;碳比 1</em>; 碳和 3* 碳更具反应性。 rxn 的试剂是 SeO2。</p>; <p>;为什么会这样？具体原因是什么？</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/q/176516</id>; <re:rank schema="https:// /chemistry.stackexchange.com">;4</re:rank>; <title type="text">;是否有像 KCl 这样的晚年矿物，但理想情况下可通过 UV/IR 重置？</stitle>; <category scheme="https:/ /chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="inorganic-chemistry">;</category>; <category schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="solid-state-chemistry">;</类别>; <类别方案=“https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags”术语=“photochemistry”>;</类别>; <类别方案=“https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags”术语=“晶体学” ">;</category>; <category schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="minerals">;</category>; <作者>; <name>;bukwyrm</name>; <uri>;https:// /chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/63066</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/176516/are-there-tenebrescent-minerals-like-kcl-but -ideally-resettable-with-uv-ir" rel="alternate"/>; <发布>;2023-09-27T09:08:54Z</发布>; <更新>;2023-09-27T20:48:22Z</更新>; <summary type="html">; <p>;是否存在一种“简单”的半月形矿物（在照射下颜色可逆地变深），但可以通过紫外线或红外线重置？</p>; <p>;Hackmanite、锂辉石和钙辉石（ <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Photochromism#Tenebrescent" rel="nofollow noreferrer">;维基百科中的暮年示例</a>;）只能通过加热来重置。 <span class="math-container">;$\ce{KCl}$</span>; 在 <span class="math-container">;$\pu{9 kV}$ 中受到电子轰击时发生颜色变化</span>;范围（很好），但也只能通过加热来重置。</p>; <p>;我正在寻找一种（理想的“简单”，又名不是方钠石<span class="math-container">;$ \ce{Na8(Al6Si6O24)Cl2}$</span>;，尽管我承认它和钾盐 <span class="math-container">;$\ce{KCl})$</span>; 之间没有明确的界限在任何类型的辐射下都会在可见光谱中发生颜色变化的矿物，但可以通过 <span class="math-container">;$\pu{300 nm}$</span>; 中的辐射重置为 <span class=" math-container">;$\pu{2500 nm}$</span>;范围。</p>; <p>;有这样的事情吗？有清单吗？有没有办法预测这一点？</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/q/176515</id>; <re:rank schema=" https://chemistry.stackexchange.com">;1</re:rank>; <title type="text">;淀粉和糖的燃烧之间的主要区别是什么</stitle>; <category schema="https:// Chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="energy">;</category>; <category schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="carbo Hydros">;</category>; <category schema=" https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="calorimetry">;</category>; <作者>; <名称>;托马斯</名称>; <uri>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/137941< /uri>; </author>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/176515/what-are-the-key-differences- Between-combustion-of-starch-and-sugar" rel= "alternate"/>; <published>;2023-09-27T06:50:20Z</published>; <updated>;2023-09-27T14:49:11Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;我执行了前几天使用基本的炸弹热量计进行了能量含量实验。该实验比较了含糖食物（阿诺特的小泰迪熊）和淀粉类食物（饼干）的能量释放。</p>; <p>;据观察，<strong>;淀粉类食物</strong >;<em>;更容易点燃</em>;并且<em>;保持燃烧时间更长</em>;。 <strong>;含糖食品</strong>;需要更多<em>;更多的热量才能点燃</em>;，并且<em>;不能保持燃烧那么长时间</em>;。</p>; <p>;结果发现，与<strong>;含糖食物</strong>;相比，<strong>;淀粉类食物</strong>;单位质量释放的能量<em>;更少</em>;。</p>; <p>;有吗淀粉类和含糖食物以这种方式燃烧并释放相对量的能量有什么明显的原因吗？我认为这可能是由于直链淀粉/支链淀粉的链结构与蔗糖的较小结构相比，但我不是100%确定。</p>; <p>;谢谢！</p>; </summary>; </p>;条目>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/q/176457</id>; <re:rank schema="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com">;3</re:rank>; <title type="text">;Derivation of "activity coefficient form of the Gibbs-Duhem equation"</stitle>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="physical-chemistry">; </category>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="thermodynamics">;</category>; <author>; <name>;acaduck</name>; <uri>;https://chemistry .stackexchange.com/users/123436</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/176457/derivation-of-activity-coefficient-form-of-the-gibbs -duhem-equation" rel="alternate"/>; <published>;2023-09-25T13:43:13Z</published>; <updated>;2023-09-28T15:55:51Z</updated>; <summary type="html ">; <p>;I'm trying to differentiate the excess Gibbs energy (<span class="math-container">;$G^{ex}$</span>;) to get the activity coefficient (<span class="math -container">;$\gamma_k$</span>;), which writes:</p>; <p>;<span class="math-container">;$$ \frac{\partial (G^{ex}/RT) }{\partial n_k} = \ln\gamma_k \quad (1) $$</span>;</p>; <p>;in the process of deriving the above equation, I saw some conditions are used, like:</p >; <p>;<span class="math-container">;$$ RT\sum_i n_i \left( \frac{\partial (\ln \gamma_i)}{\partial n_k} \right)_{T,P,n_ {i\neq k}} = 0 \quad (2) $$</span>;</p>; <ul>; <li>;<span class="math-container">;$n_i$</span>;: mole numbers </li>; </ul>; <p>;or</p>; <p>;<span class="math-container">;$$ x_1 \text{d} \ln \gamma_1 + x_2 \text{d} \ln \gamma_2 = 0 \quad (3) $$</span>;</p>; <ul>; <li>;<span class="math-container">;$x_i$</span>; mole fractions</li>; </ ul>; <p>;<strong>;I'm wondering how (2) and (3) are derived?</strong>; I saw they were mentiond as "activity coefficient form of the Gibbs-Duhem equation"</p>; < p>;but how Gibbs-Duhem equation</p>; <p>;<span class="math-container">;$$ \sum_i n_i \text{d} \mu_i = 0 $$</span>;</p>; < p>;becomes (2) or (3) are unclear to me.</p>; <p>;<strong>;References:</strong>;</p>; <ul>; <li>;(1) and (2) from < em>;Thermodynamics and Its Applications by Tester and Modell</em>;, P357-358</li>; <li>;（3）from Wikipedia <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gibbs%E2 %80%93Duhem_equation" rel="nofollow noreferrer">;here</a>;</li>; </ul>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/q /175049</id>; <re:rank scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com">;2</re:rank>; <title type="text">;Reduction of La(NO3)3 to La(NO2 )3</stitle>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="experimental-chemistry">;</category>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/ tags" term="redox">;</category>; <author>; <name>;liuzp</name>; <uri>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/66426</uri>; </author>; <link href ="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/175049/reduction-of-lano33-to-lano23" rel="alternate"/>; <published>;2023-07-17T13:03:59Z</published>; < updated>;2023-09-28T18:56:11Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;I'm writing a master's thesis on some lanthanide compounds, in particular those with <span class="math-container ">;$\ce{Ce^{+3}}$</span>; and <span class="math-container">;$\ce{La^{+3}}$</span>;, although my focus has now shifted to lanthanum, but I ran into a problem when I could not precipitate my anion, which is a coordination compound, with lanthanum so to solve this problem I modified my reaction setup to start with <span class="math-container">; $\ce{La(NO2)3}$</span>; instead of <span class="math-container">;$\ce{NaNO2}$</span>; so that when I want to precipitate the coordination compound I don 't have those pesky sodium ions around.</p>; <p>;The thing is, I only have a <span class="math-container">;$\ce{La(NO3)3}$</span>; in store, so I was wondering if there is a way to reduce the nitrate ion to nitrite without changing the lanthanide oxidation number.</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange .com/q/172397</id>; <re:rank scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com">;0</re:rank>; <title type="text">;Non-Constant Pressure and Temperature Processes - Gibbs Energy as Equilibrium Condition</stitle>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="thermodynamics">;</category>; <author>; <name>;Aurelius611</name>; <uri >;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/132534</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/172397/non-constant-pressure-and-temperature -processes-gibbs-energy-as-equilibrium-co" rel="alternate"/>; <published>;2023-03-25T13:24:10Z</published>; <updated>;2023-09-29T03:18:47Z</ updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;I reviewed several questions already, but none address the same point except the following:</p>; <p>;<a href="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com /questions/127834/is-gibbs-energy-minimized-for-processes-at-constant-temperature-are-pressure-onl">;Is Gibbs energy minimized for processes at constant temperature are pressure only?</a>;</p >; <p>;However, this question remains unanswered until today. The derivations and equations below are from Robin Smith's Chemical Process Design (Chapter 5) and Kolt's Chemical Thermodynamics (Chapter 6 and 7)</p>; <hr />; <p>;For the calculation of the equilibrium constant, it is the case the <span class="math-container">;$\Delta G$</span>; is set to zero at the equilibrium condition. However, doing so seem improper from what I know, and I am wondering what I am getting wrong.</p>; <p>;I am considering a reaction of ideal gases, in which the total pressure is changing while the reaction is progressing. As the reaction progress, Gibbs energy can be described by the following correct equation:</p>; <p>;<span class="math-container">;$\Delta G_{rxn} = \Delta G - \Delta G^0=RT\ln{K}$</span>;</p>; <p>;However, it is claimed that at equilibrium <span class="math-container">;$\Delta G = 0$</span>;. Therefore,</p>; <p>;<span class="math-container">;$\Delta G^0=-RT\ln{K_{eq}}$</span>;</p>; <p>;This latter equation is the one I am concerned with due to the imposition that <span class="math-container">;$\Delta G = 0$</span>;, which does not seem proper as the pressure is changing while the reaction is progressing. My concern stems from the logic detailed below.</p>; <hr />; <hr />; <hr />; <p>;The standard thermodynamic condition for equilibrium is <span class="math-container">;$dS_{tot} = 0$</span>;. This then can lead to an equilibrium condition involving Gibbs energy as follows:</p>; <p>;<span class="math-container">;$dS_{total} = dS_{env}+dS_{sys}$</span>;</p>; <p>;Re-Writing the equilibrium condition in terms of system variables only gives:</p>; <p>;<span class="math-container">;$dS_{sys} = \frac{DQ_{sys}}{T_{sys}} $</span>;</p>; <p>;This assumes <span class="math-container">;$T_{env} = T_{sys}$</span>;</p>; <p>;Embedding the first law of thermodynamics and assuming only PV work leaves us with:</p>; <p>;<span class="math-container">;$dU+Pdv - TdS = 0$</span>;</p>; <p>;Imposing the assumption of constant temperature and pressure allows adding P and T differentials since they are zeros.</p>; <p>;<span class="math-container">;$dU+PdV + VdP - TdS - SdT = 0$</span>;</p>; <p>;Once integrated, this gives:</p>; <p>;<span class="math-container">;$\Delta U + \Delta (PV) - T\Delta S = 0 $</span>;</p>; <p>;or equivalently</p>; <p>;<span class="math-container">;$\Delta H - T \Delta S = 0$</span>; with <span class="math-container">;$\Delta G = \Delta H - T \Delta S$</span>;</p>; <p>;However, this final result only came to be with the assumption that <span class="math-container">;$dP$</span>; and <span class="math-container">;$dT$</span>; are zero. If this assumption is removed, the equilibrium condition differential would be as follows:</p>; <p>;<span class="math-container">;$dU+Pdv + VdP - TdS - SdT = -VdP - SdT$</span>;</p>; <p>;or</p>; <p>;<span class="math-container">;$dG = VdP - SdT$</span>;</p>; <p>;This latter equation does not produce <span class="math-container">;$\Delta G = 0$</span>;. In fact, the <span class="math-container">;$\Delta G$</span>; and <span class="math-container">;$K$</span>; relation is derived from it. The end result is that we are applying an equation for constant pressure and another with non-constant pressure for the same system at the same time; this does not make sense to me, as pressure is either constant or not.</p>; <p>;How is it then that <span class="math-container">;$\Delta G^0=-RT\ln{K_{eq}}$</span>;?</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/q/169692</id>; <re:rank scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com">;5</re:rank>; <title type="text">;What is the mechanism of Salkowski reaction of сholesterols?</stitle>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="organic-chemistry">;</category>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="reaction-mechanism">;</category>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="analytical-chemistry">;</category>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="lipids">;</category>; <author>; <name>;Cyclopropanol</name>; <uri>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/113430</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/169692/what-is-the-mechanism-of-salkowski-reaction-of-%d1%81holesterols" rel="alternate"/>; <published>;2022-12-03T12:46:17Z</published>; <updated>;2023-09-29T11:05:34Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;I recently came across the Salkowski reaction of cholesterols. Cholesterol in chloroform is treated with concentrated sulfuric acid. A positive test exhibits two distinct layers, the upper chloroform layer gets a red to violet colour, while the lower sulfuric acid layer exhibits a greenish glow.</p>; <ol>; <li>;<p>;The chemistry behind the reaction is dehydration using <span class="math-container">;$\ce{H2SO4},$</span>; forming cholestadiene.</p>; <p>;<a href="https://i.stack.imgur.com/jyI4s.png" rel="nofollow noreferrer">;<img src="https://i.stack.imgur.com/jyI4s.png" alt="dehydration of сholesterol" />;</a>;</p>; </li>; <li>;<p>;In the second step, the cholestadiene undergoes dimerization.</p>; <p>;<a href="https://i.stack.imgur.com/HOZXc.png" rel="nofollow noreferrer">;<img src="https://i.stack.imgur.com/HOZXc.png" alt="dimerization of cholestadiene" />;</a>;</p>; </li>; <li>;<p>;In the last step, the cholestadiene undergoes sulfonation at the 7,7' position. (I believe I drew the correct structure)</p>; <p>;<a href="https://i.stack.imgur.com/ojs82.png" rel="nofollow noreferrer">;<img src="https://i.stack.imgur.com/ojs82.png" alt="sulfonation of cholestadiene" />;</a>;</p>; </li>; </ol>; <p>;However, I couldn't find a <em>;valid mechanism</em>; for the second and the third steps (dimerization and sulfonation). Can someone explain the mechanism?</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/q/151227</id>; <re:rank scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com">;6</re:rank>; <title type="text">;Why is the aqueous solution of KMnO4 slightly basic?</stitle>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="physical-chemistry">;</category>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="acid-base">;</category>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="aqueous-solution">;</category>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="ph">;</category>; <author>; <name>;harry</name>; <uri>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/83666</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/151227/why-is-the-aqueous-solution-of-kmno4-slightly-basic" rel="alternate"/>; <published>;2021-05-09T11:34:19Z</published>; <updated>;2023-09-27T20:50:23Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;This is in the context of the various changes in oxidation state the permangananate ion can undergo with the variation of the pH of the medium. Besides the cases of strongly basic and strongly acidic media, the case for neutral media (with reduction to <span class="math-container">;$\ce{MnO2}$</span>;) in my notes has a footnote; that this medium is in fact slightly alkaline, due to it being a solution of <span class="math-container">;$\ce{KMnO4}$</span>;.</p>; <p>;I tried to reason this out. It looks like <span class="math-container">;$$\ce{K+ + MnO4- + H2O -> K+ + OH- + HMnO4}$$</span>; is how it works out.</p>; <p>;A quick google search establishes the pKa of HMnO4 to be -2.25. So it makes a pretty good acid in comparison to water.</p>; <p>;Thing is, in that case, the product side should have an <span class="math-container">;$\ce{H2O}$</span>; instead of the constituent ions, with the potassium permanganate dissociated. That means the solution's neutral. Which apparently it isn't, going with my notes.</p>; <p>;Where did I mess up here?</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/q/126845</id>; <re:rank scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com">;5</re:rank>; <title type="text">;Is there an anisotropy factor (g factor) for TDDFT Abs and CD calculations?</stitle>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="quantum-chemistry">;</category>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="spectroscopy">;</category>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="chirality">;</category>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="uv-vis-spectroscopy">;</category>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="td-dft">;</category>; <author>; <name>;C. Alexander</name>; <uri>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/87905</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/126845/is-there-an-anisotropy-factor-g-factor-for-tddft-abs-and-cd-calculations" rel="alternate"/>; <published>;2020-01-21T16:06:33Z</published>; <updated>;2023-09-28T18:18:25Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;Experimentally, anisotropy factor is calculated by dividing the CD spectra by the absorbance spectra multiplying by a factor of 32980 (in order to get a nondimensional quantity)</p>; <p>;Theoretical calculations can be performed via TDDFT to obtain rotatory and oscillatory strengths, obtaining excitations for each case and adjusting, for each excitation, a curve, obtaining then the "theoretical absorbance/CD spectra".</p>; <p>;How can then we define a theoretical anisotropy factor, does it have sense? Should another calculation be performed?</p>; <p>;Would you divide both adjusted curves or divide the corresponding excitations, adjusting a new set of curves to what you get?</p>; <p>;Any clues?</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/q/78685</id>; <re:rank scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com">;-1</re:rank>; <title type="text">;Calcium-containing acidic solution</stitle>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="solutions">;</category>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="ph">;</category>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="precipitation">;</category>; <author>; <name>;Mohammad</name>; <uri>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/48544</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/78685/calcium-containing-acidic-solution" rel="alternate"/>; <published>;2017-07-12T11:18:39Z</published>; <updated>;2023-09-28T05:59:17Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;I want to prepare an acidic solution containing Ca ions. I thought about dissolving calcium sulphate, acetate or phosphate in <span class="math-container">;$\pu{2 M}$</span>; <span class="math-container">;$\ce{H2SO4}$</span>; or <span class="math-container">;$\ce{H3PO4}$</span>; solutions, but it seems that <span class="math-container">;$\ce{Ca}$</span>; cations react with sulphate anions.</p>; <p>;Is it true? And is there any way to make a <span class="math-container">;$\ce{Ca}$</span>;-containing acidic solution?</p>; <p>;(I forgot to say I need <span class="math-container">;$\ce{Cl}$</span>; & <span class="math-container">;$\ce{F}$</span>; free solution...)</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/q/71980</id>; <re:rank scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com">;17</re:rank>; <title type="text">;Why is anhydrous copper(II) sulfate white while the pentahydrate is blue, even though both have one unpaired electron?</stitle>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="inorganic-chemistry">;</category>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="coordination-compounds">;</category>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="transition-metals">;</category>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="color">;</category>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="crystal-field-theory">;</category>; <author>; <name>;Kartik</name>; <uri>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/5710</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/71980/why-is-anhydrous-copperii-sulfate-white-while-the-pentahydrate-is-blue-even-t" rel="alternate"/>; <published>;2017-04-05T07:19:02Z</published>; <updated>;2023-09-27T17:33:42Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;We all know that <span class="math-container">;$\ce{CuSO4.5H2O}$</span>; is blue and it turns to <span class="math-container">;$\ce{CuSO4}$</span>; on heating which is white. I also learnt about coordination complexes and d–d transitions and how transition metal compounds are colored. Recently I came to know that <span class="math-container">;$\ce{CuSO4.5H2O}$</span>; is also a coordination compound and in its structure four water molecules are coordinated with <span class="math-container">;$\ce{Cu^2+}$</span>; and one is hydrogen-bonded to <span class="math-container">;$\ce{SO4^2-}.$</span>; So, I thought lets try to apply the theory here and see what causes the blue color of copper sulfate.</p>; <p>;<span class="math-container">;$\ce{CuSO4}$</span>; has <span class="math-container">;$\ce{Cu^2+}$</span>; ions and I wrote down the electronic configuration as <span class="math-container">;$\mathrm{(3d)^9(4s)^0}.$</span>; Since no d–d transition is possible, it should be white.</p>; <p>;<span class="math-container">;$\ce{CuSO4.5H2O}$</span>; is actually <span class="math-container">;$\ce{[Cu(H2O)4]SO4.H2O}$</span>; and the complex ion is <span class="math-container">;$\ce{[Cu(H2O)4]^2+}$</span>;. <span class="math-container">;$\ce{H2O}$</span>; is a weak field ligand, therefore the electronic configuration is <span class="math-container">;$\mathrm{(3d)^9(4s)^2(4p)^6}.$</span>; But still no d–d transition is possible, so it should also be white!? What went wrong in my estimation?</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/q/59534</id>; <re:rank scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com">;7</re:rank>; <title type="text">;What is crystallographic equivalence?</stitle>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="crystal-structure">;</category>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="materials">;</category>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="solid-state-chemistry">;</category>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="x-ray-diffraction">;</category>; <author>; <name>;lightweaver</name>; <uri>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/15465</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/59534/what-is-crystallographic-equivalence" rel="alternate"/>; <published>;2016-09-22T15:08:47Z</published>; <updated>;2023-09-28T16:35:14Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;I've learnt that in crystallography, there are many crystallographic directions that are “equivalent.” For example, in a cubic crystal system, the [011] and [110] and [101] directions are “crystallographically equivalent.” See the image below:</p>; <p>;<a href="https://i.stack.imgur.com/UoaeN.jpg" rel="noreferrer">;<img src="https://i.stack.imgur.com/UoaeN.jpg" alt="enter image description here">;</a>;</p>; <p>;I cannot begin to fathom how they are equivalent. These are vectors after all, and from what I can tell with my rudimentary knowledge of maths, these vectors are not equivalent in direction. Yet all materials science textbooks and powerpoints <em>;insist</em>; that, for cubic systems, any permutation of positive and negative indices will yield a same equivalent direction. That is, the [011], [110], and [101] vectors are… the same vector?</p>; <p>;I share the same confusion with planes, even if they aren't vectors. For cubic systems, just as for directions, any arrangement of positive and negative indices produces an equivalent plane. For example, (100) and (010) are the same plane, when to me they clearly look different.</p>; <p>;So what exactly is “crystallographic equivalence”?</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/q/24769</id>; <re:rank scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com">;7</re:rank>; <title type="text">;Why Ca 2+ and not Ca +2</stitle>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="nomenclature">;</category>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="ions">;</category>; <author>; <name>;Simon-Nail-It</name>; <uri>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/9757</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/24769/why-ca-2-and-not-ca-2" rel="alternate"/>; <published>;2015-02-07T10:35:09Z</published>; <updated>;2023-09-29T12:47:23Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;I have been learning chemistry for a year or two but I still can't understand this. According to maths we should place the plus or minus sign in front of a number like -2. However, In chemistry we always put the sign behind a number when writing ions like $\ce{Ba^2+}$ ,$\ce{Cu^2+}$, $\ce{O^2-}$ etc. So, I want to know why do we write it that way?</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/q/13802</id>; <re:rank scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com">;3</re:rank>; <title type="text">;I heard aluminium doesn't produce fumes when burnt but the opposite happened, how?</stitle>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="safety">;</category>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="metal">;</category>; <category scheme="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/tags" term="combustion">;</category>; <author>; <name>;Random kid</name>; <uri>;https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/users/6911</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://chemistry.stackexchange.com/questions/13802/i-heard-aluminium-doesnt-produce-fumes-when-burnt-but-the-opposite-happened-ho" rel="alternate"/>; <published>;2014-06-22T10:26:02Z</published>; <updated>;2023-09-29T02:20:18Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;One day I took aluminium foil(sanitary brand, don't know if you've heard it) then I casually burned it over a gas lighter then it burned and gave off Grey fumes and the foil became a dull Grey where it had burnt. I mistakenly may have inhaled a bit of fumes. I had a slight pain in my right nostril the whole day.那个怎么样？ Is that dangerous? </p>; </summary>; </entry>; </feed>;
